Resident
2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/11/2017
The management of West Village is completely unethical. Before I signed the lease I repeatedly asked about the total expense of utilities and was told it would be between $150-160/month. I never use my dishwasher or put my air conditioning below 76 and just got my first utility bill which is well over $250. Management told me I could pay them for the spectrum wifi and cable (which we are forced to pay either to them or First Billing for $100/ month even though Spectrum offers more extensive services for $29.99) and then First Billing still billed me because West Village never received their payment. West village never informed me of overpaying, and so was obviously planning on pocketing the money. The management claims the apartments are gated but every other week the fobs to my apartment aren't working and they just put up a sign and leave the doors propped open. They don't answer their emails 9/10 times and refuse to do simple repairs to very old apartments. I should have researched more before signing a lease. Oh also, there's a clause in the lease that says the lease can't be changed, even under extreme circumstances like personal or family illness. All other apartments I've ever heard of allow you to pay a penalty and leave if something extreme comes up like a severe illness when the tenet is unable to pay due to medical fees. When I've asked to speak to corporate contact, management at West Village refused, telling me there was no such thing, even though all I had to do was google it to find the Connor Group contact information.

Report
Prospective Resident
Visited 2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/04/2017
I've lived here for a couple years now and have made quite a few friends in the building. After conversation with most of them, it has come to light that their base offer at the end of your lease is to increase your rent by $250. If you say you're going to move out, they immediately contact you back with a $50 offer. This has happened with at least 4 people that I've talked to. If you plan on living here expect at least a $50 rent increase per year. The lady at the office tried to justify this by saying that it was less than moving cost so it was a better option than moving. They are basically banking on the fact that you won't move to raise rent by a $600/year. The cable bill has gone up from $65-$90 with no change in plan. The trash bill has gone up from $20-$45 with a reduction in service (used to pickup 5 days a week, now pick up 3 days a week). I've also heard mixed comments from residents about whether or not they are forced to pay for parking. I wasn't but a few of my neighbors have. The gym is packed most of the day so good luck getting a workout in the morning or evening hours. If you're not in a parking spot by 8pm, good luck finding parking. On op of that, my hallway smells like cigarettes (6th floor) and nothing has been done about it. Overall, this place is overrated and over priced. Only thing that got me here was the central location but with other options popping up around Durham, I'd avoid this place.

2016 - 2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/23/2017
Latest Update: Today, as we signed our new lease, we were informed of a mandatory up-charge on our already useless cable. Once a rediculous $65/mo charge (you've NO choice on this), we now are going to be charged $99. This, on top of a mandatory $45 monthly charge for "valet" garbage pick-up, which is also increasing, and a fee for your apt washer and dryer, which you must pay. We're out in several months. That's our big break. If YOU want a break, don't waste your time, energy and money joining this "beautiful community." You've plenty of other terrific options now in Durham.

anonymous 09/25/2017

Could not agree more with my experience at west village. The leasing staff is completely incompetent and apathetic. It took west village more than 2 months to send me my security deposit when North Carolina general statutes clearly dictate that security deposits must be refunded within 30 days of lease termination. At one point after the leasing staff neglected to record my forwarding address for the third time, I was told &quot;You set up mail forwarding right? Well, you should see it eventually.&quot; WOW! Maybe that should have been my attitude with paying rent.

Resident
2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/05/2017
I moved into West Village apts in July 2017 and its been a nightmare every since I moved in I recently reached out to upper management because the office staff lies and tell you they will get back to you yet they never do. here is a copy of my letter. What good is a nice apt if you cant enjoy it The Conner Group: I am writing this letter in regards to the issues that I have experienced since I moved into West Village Apartments on July 10,2017. Upon signing my lease I made it clear that I opposed the mandatory Cable/Internet fee of $100. Citing "Trying to promote pay-TV competition and keep prices in check, the Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously Wednesday to wipe out deals giving cable operators exclusive access to apartments, condos and other centrally managed real estate developments."-FCC. Alexis the leasing agent who handled my move in had knowledge of my discontent and I ask to speak with the property Manager at move in she assured me I would get a call which I did not. I refuse to sign the form that stated that I agreed with this service. Last Thursday August 31,2017 I was able to speak with Stephany one of the Managers I expressed my discontent about the cable to her, she looked into my file and verified that had sign the addendum but the agreement of the exclusive cable company. I was told that she would get back to me after talking to her Manager which I have yet to get a response. As a consumer I am entitled to spend my money the way I chooses and not be forced to use a service that I don't want. The second issue that concerns me is that I was promised stainless steal appliances when I came in April to see the apt. Upon move in no stainless steal appliances, I was told they were on backorder which annoyed me because I was promised back in April I didn't move in till July, West Village labels itself as a luxury apartments; stainless steel appliances are basic amenities in luxury apt. Around Aug 20, 2017 I was very happy to see my appliances delivered, however as of this writing most of the appliances are sitting in my living room still in boxes. This is unacceptable as the holiday just past and I could not enjoy the luxury of entertaining my in LUXURY apt. Also its advertised as a gated community however our gate stay open over night, as a parent this concerns me I not paying to live in a open gated community. West Village makes a lot of claims which they have been failing to live up too, the hallways are cluttered with boxes that tenants have set out and have stayed there for a whole month instead of telling the tenant that the trash collector doesn't accept cardboard boxes and that they are responsible for disposing of their cardboard it sits there and makes the hallway look very bad. I have been very unhappy living here and it's only been 2 months I want to be able to enjoy where I live unfortunately I haven't I hope this problems will be resolved ASAP. When you advertise a service you have an obligation to deliver and if you don't your breaching your contract thus far West Village is in breach of contract for not providing the services they claim to offer.

anonymous 09/18/2017

in which building do you live? Let me share with you my complaints with being displaced for 4+ weeks while the apartment complex &quot;looks after your renovations&quot; and actually NO ONE was looking after restorations. 100+ year old pine wood floors. ALMOST. and I mean almost. RUINED. because it took 5+days to get a restoration crew there. After a contracted maintenance crew knocked off a sprinkler head, while neglecting to turn off the water, subsequently locked themselves out, and then had to kick in my front door. My front door was unsecured for 3+ days. I'm still waiting on repairs as communication between corporate/local/insurance has been LESS than ideal. I still don't have a functional front door - not to mention my dog and daughter (6) and the glass mirrored door that was shattered and still continues to shed glass - I don't want either my dog or my daughter to walk into broken glass. I was still expected to pay rent in the 5+ weeks that I was displaced. Even when I was told to move out of the hotel I am still waiting for the insurance checks to replace the furniture that was destroyed - seriously, the only thing I had to sit in was my office chair. But &quot;hey were &quot;providing me with a place to stay&quot;. and I understand that in North Carolina this is common practice. it just sucks. I'm a single mom, I saved and overlapped moving by a month - LITERALLY on the last trip to pick up things from my old house was when I received the phone call informing me there had been &quot;an incident&quot; in my apartment.

Resident
2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/24/2017
Don't do it! We should have been more wary when the leasing agent rushed us into signing a lease. The management is absolutely horrible, both in timeliness and professionalism. We received no information prior to moving in, several other tenants leases that they had signed were cancelled by management and they were given a different apartment on move-in day without any prior notification, security in the garage is minimal and people's bikes get stolen even though it is "secured" the garage entry door is left open most days. If you have a problem in your apartment and call the office someone will say it will be taken care of, and then nothing will happen. You will then call back, requiring you to talk to MULTIPLE agents who each will tell you they will pass along the message (which doesn't happen). I was not aware prior to coming here that the management had changed to Connor group in January, 2017 resulting in upwards of $500 rent increases as well as just complete incompetency. There are several new apartment complexes in the surrounding area with MUCH better managing companies (Liberty warehouse, etc), and I would highly recommend looking into those. While the location is great, they have been getting away with bad customer service because of it, but now that there is significant competition nearby I would really think about the decision to live with West Village. My experience is also not solitary, as there are many residents who had similar situations, do your research and talk to current residents before signing this place!

Resident
2016 - 2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/11/2017
There's no denying that West Village apartments are located in a great spot downtown; however, that's pretty much where the pros end. Cons: management staff is extremely rude and condescending - do not expect to EVER receive an email or call back and you will eventually have to go into the office where they claim your issue will be solved (it never will) - people say the gym is nice... yes it's big, but HALF of the equipment is broken or needs maintenance and the gym is disgustingly dirty. The yoga room has no ventilation and smells horrible. - security: the gates are never locked, and our doors to our building have been propped open by newspapers for the past three days because "the card scanners is broken"... - maintenance: the tub in my unit (mind you the only shower) currently has 3 feet of standing freezing water that my roommate and I have to use for "48 hours because maintenance is backed up" - rent payments: they WILL try to con you out of money at some point during your stay here I would never recommend moving into West Village. Initially, I thought the style and amenities were awesome, but the lack of customer service and downright rudeness of the management is sure to turn anyone away.

Resident
2016 - 2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/11/2017
We were made the promise of new appliances that have yet to materialize. It's false advertising to say an apartment is going to receive updated appliances and then to just pretend it was never communicated to a tenant or customer. The failure to respond to maintenance requests is the most APPALLING part of our experience at West Village. My wife and I are currently dealing with an issue that could have been resolved if taken seriously when we first reported it 8 months ago. Now we've had to leave our apartment so our kitchen and bathrooms can be treated creating a huge inconvenience for us and our pets. And if we do ever receive any communication responding to our maintenance requests or communications to the main office it's never clear who we are talking to and every conversation is like starting from scratch. The only time the office takes an email or maintenance request seriously is when you copy the Connor Group and express your displeasure at the multiple previous emails that have not been responded to. Living in Downtown Durham is amazing but living at West Village is AWFUL and nobody should move in to this complex. We sincerely regret our decision to do so, will not renew our lease and encourage everyone considering moving here to look elsewhere.

2010 - 2017 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/06/2017
Since Connor Group began managing West Village, customer service has spiraled down as they focus on cosmetic improvements but are unable to track payments, do not enforce pet policy (pet waste is frequently found in hallways and other public areas), have created a dis-functional package delivery system, do not enforce noise policies, ended the on-call courtesy patrol and tells residents for call the police if they have an issue, do not keep common areas clean (the trash point for Flowers building is probably a health hazard), do not enforce trash placement in the hallways (trash bags sit in front of apartment doors all day and through the weekend: both unsightly and smelly), increased laundry machine charge by 60% without notice, have a junior staff that prevents access to facility management, etc, etc.

Resident
2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/05/2017
I've lived at West Village for a year and am signing a new lease (different unit--moving to a 2 bedroom) for this upcoming year. I'm very happy with the location--walking distance from everything: bars, restaurants, breweries, all the surround neighborhoods (i.e. Brightleaf, Tobacco cmapus). I feel safe walking in the area and it's very dog friendly. The amenities are great as well (beautiful pools, courtyards, gym, etc.). Only area of improvement would be communication by the leasing office. They are pretty last minute with their newsletters and sharing of information and I often have to wait for maintenance requests. They mean well, they just seem a little disorganized.

Resident
2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 03/21/2017
I've lived in Durham for two years and am so happy I found the West Village apartments! The location is super ideal - walking distance to downtown shopping, restaurants and bars, and it's near public transportation. The complex itself is very impressive - three major parking lots (including a secured garage), two pools (kept very clean and one is open year-round), playgrounds, grill areas, a gym and a business center. My roommate and I have also been very happy with maintenance and management. Any requests we've had for repairs or help from management have been answered promptly (our main office liaison is Shay and she's been awesome and extremely helpful with all of our questions/requests). I highly recommend the West Village for families, grad students and professionals!

Resident
2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 03/16/2017
I've been here just under a year now and really enjoy my apartment. You can't beat WV's location anywhere else in downtown. The units are really cool with exposed brick in the older buildings, but sometimes you can hear your neighbors through the floors/walls. Shay has been amazing with everything so far with my experiences at the office. Unfortunately rent prices are a bit inflated, so it will be interesting to see what the leasing office does to combat the competitive pricing at other apartment communities in the area. Overall the location is great and the loft-style units are really unique which makes for a great living environment.

I moved into West Village apartments in November 2016. Reagan Vaughan was my leasing agent, and I applaud her for such a warm and welcoming experience. Understandably with that at times noise will carry between apartments and I would simply say talk to your neighbor if it ever really gets that bad. The front office is also always willing to help but I believe this is the nature of just living in ANY apartment you can't account for the behaviors of people who are just not willing to live civilly or respect their neighbors. I've called for maintenance only once in my unit and maintenance fixed the minor problem immediately and I have not to call back again. The area is Fabulous you are close to dining, entertainment - The DPAC, Carolina Theater and in walking distance to almost everything. This is the heart of downtown living. You also have some Duke offices in the main lobby and you are very close to Duke East campus and the great Ninth street area. I am looking forward to the summer of 2017 to spread my wings and take in all the sites and local city events of Durham.

2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 01/12/2017
I've been a resident in the Moore Building (Phase3) at West Village for several months and have really enjoyed my experience living downtown. I can walk anywhere I need to go... work, church, the DBAP ball park, the DPAC theater, parks, shops, and restaurants/cafes/breweries galore. One of my favorite things to do is walk to the Saturday farmer's market and weekend food truck rodeos. I especially love watching the sun rise over downtown every morning as the city begins to wake up. I thought having a dog in the city was going to be difficult but I've found that we're actually more active with the easy access to Duke's east campus and other walking trails. I also really appreciate that our parking is secure - that's hard to find downtown. I'll also add that I'm a professional in my 30's and have found this to be a quiet and enjoyable place to live. In my experience, the West Village staff has been very helpful. This is a huge property and, still, they know who I am and greet me by name. They've been very attentive and prompt replying to the few maintance or building-related requests I've made. In particular, Shay is absolutely wonderful, and I really appreciate Brittney's dedication and friendliness. I could go on, but the bottom line is that you can't beat the location and low-maintainance living. Yes, you pay for it, but their prices are fairly comparable to the rest of the market downtown and on 9th Street.

Great location with a very cool aesthetic. But the high ceilings and being on the first floor allow me to hear pretty much every neighbor on each side of me. The price point is higher than some in the area, but I suppose that's justified by the location. overall it's a fine apartment if you can afford it. Resident
2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 11/04/2016
We have lived in the West Village for 8 months now and we couldn't be more pleased with the entire package. The location is prime in downtown Durham, NC. The staff is attentive, friendly, and well qualified. The renovated tobacco factory lofts are beautiful and "historical chic" with exposed piping, wood beams and floors, and granite countertops. The large windows allow for ample natural light and lovely views of the adjacent brick facades and urban landscape. Kia, Shay, and Alexis form an amazing sales/management team and they will greet you, and all your requests, with the utmost professionalism and timely response. Pedro and his maintenance crew are quick to service all repairs. Residency also includes access to two pools, a well-equiped gym, and courtyards with gas grills. Trash collection, cable/wifi, and utilities are not included in the rent but the rates are standard and metered. NC and Durham have no rent control policies so your lease is annually reassessed for market value. In our search for rental housing in the triangle, we viewed numerous properties but West Village stood out from all the rest and continues to exceed our expectations. We would highly recommend this apartment community.

Report
Resident
2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 09/01/2016
I moved into the West Village Apartments back in January of 2016, and have been living here for about 8 whole months in the Moore building. Thus far I'm very happy with the West Village Apartments. The rent is probably the most expensive of the Durham area luxury apartments, and definitely from a space perspective you can get more space for less money. However, the location of the West village simply can't be beat, and in my opinion thats the reason why the price is justified. 1 mile from Whole Foods for groceries, 2 blocks from the farmers market, walking distance to DPAC, downtown Durham, and the Tobacco campus. If you have to travel its about a 20 minute drive to RDU, which is pretty close. Duke Hospital is around 5 minutes away. For me personally, my work is a 10 minute commute. To a large extend you are paying for the convenience. The amenities of the apartments are also quite nice. The gym is probably the largest I've seen of all the luxury apartments, and they have a great pool thats easy to get to. High powered grills were recently added making BBQ'ing fairly easy. In the Moore building also has a parking garage under the building and its never full, so parking is great especially if its raining and you have groceries to carry. My only negative is that in the 8 months I've been at West Village the fire alarm has gone off in the middle of the night 3 times for non-fire related things. I think this is fixed but it was a bit annoying. Additionally, it can be noisy from the train that passes by at night. That being said I basically don't hear my neighbors at all. Plus I can make a ton of noise and I haven't heard any complaints from the neighbors, so sound between units is quite good. There is a feeling that because the rent is so high, there should be zero problems can occasionally stuff happens. But thats life and in the grand scheme of things, I haven't observed too many issues.
I moved into the West Village Apartments back in January of 2016, and have been living here for about 8 whole months in the Moore building. Thus far I'm very happy with the West Village Apartments. The rent is probably the most expensive of the Durham area luxury apartments, and definitely from a space perspective you can get more space for less money. However, the location of the West village simply can't be beat, and in my opinion thats the reason why the price is justified. 1 mile from Whole Foods for groceries, 2 blocks from the farmers market, walking distance to DPAC, downtown Durham, and the Tobacco campus. If you have to travel its about a 20 minute drive to RDU, which is pretty close. Duke Hospital is around 5 minutes away. For me personally, my work is a 10 minute commute. To a large extend you are paying for the convenience. The amenities of the apartments are also quite nice. The gym is probably the largest I've seen of all the luxury apartments, and they have a great pool thats easy to get to. High powered grills were recently added making BBQ'ing fairly easy. In the Moore building also has a parking garage under the building and its never full, so parking is great especially if its raining and you have groceries to carry. My only negative is that in the 8 months I've been at West Village the fire alarm has gone off in the middle of the night 3 times for non-fire related things. I think this is fixed but it was a bit annoying. Additionally, it can be noisy from the train that passes by at night. That being said I basically don't hear my neighbors at all. True, the management changed recently but I have found them to be nothing but helpful and friendly; I think it is reasonable to expect a bit of chaos during a transition. Negatives: - maintenance requests are slow and sometimes unresponsive - I'm hoping that is due to the management-transition. - one side of walls in apartment are paper thin. Resident
2014 - 2016 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/24/2016
Sadly the last reviewer is right, since the new management company a lot has gone down quickly except for the price for Valet trash pick up doubled, price for a pet went up from $18 to $45 per month, so far the rents ( I was paying $1,700 for my 2 bedroom) have increased dramatically (not just $100 but several hundreds of dollars more per month) there is now trash around the community that doesn't get picked up regularly, the recycling bin next to the mailboxes was so full that the items were being piled up on top and falling over, the garbage can in the garage by the elevator also gets so overfilled that old discarded food bags are falling next to it, you don't see people cleaning as frequently as before, so the elevator floor can get pretty dirty often, for a while the doggie poop bags were gone so no surprise people started not picking that up in the courtyard area, doors on the interior of the buildings are broken and not fixed, it takes a long time to get a response for maintenance issues, the system for paying now requires 2 different systems one for rent and the other for the utilities trash and pet fee, there is a convenience charge for that one. There has been very little communication from the new management company as to why they have decided to charge a lot more while cutting back on the overall cleanliness and services in the community or even what their plan is for this community. There have been a lot of people moving out since the new management company started around March and there is no sign that any of the prior maintenance issues like the sometimes smelly hallways, the really old and dirty carpet (there are even more stains in the hallways since there are fewer people cleaning) will ever be taken care of. I really liked it here for the last two years, but it is time to go.

Resident
2013 - 2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/28/2014
Have lived at West Village for almost a year in the Cooper Shop #604 building. Overall we have been happy here. Our apartment has a lot of character with high ceilings, exposed brick, rustic wood floors and some old features from when this was a factory or warehouse. Also, we have a huge outdoor space, which is awesome. The grounds are very well kept, the gym is new and huge. The pool area is nice, but small, considering there are several hundred apartments here. Maintenance seemed very efficient when we first moved in, but has become a bit slower to respond. The fact that the apartment walls don't go all the way up to the ceiling can be a bit of an issue at times. This is one of the reasons we are moving out. The other reason is that the value isn't great. You can get a lot more for your money in other areas, a bit away from downtown. We haven't had noise issues from partying students in this building, which is in general pretty quiet. The main noise problem comes from the apartment above us, which is probably not the fault of the tenant, but the lack of insulation between the floors. I was told that there is no concrete layer between floors in this building. When the tenant above us walks around, it sounds like he/she is stomping as hard as they can. It also frequently sounds as if a bowling ball is being rolled across the floor:-0 This problem is made worse since the "stomping" can be heard very often way past midnight, and very early (5-6) in the morning. The location is great if you like to be able to walk to bars and restaurants downtown, and the Carolina Theatre and DPAC. There is also a running track at Duke East Campus, about a 5 min walk away.

2013 - 2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/01/2014
Opinion: You can get the same amenities at a cheaper price within reasonable distance to downtown and Duke somewhere else. Background: I'm a Duke graduate student/young professional living in a 2BR apartment at West Village. Cons: 1. Smelly halls- At West Village, we must pay for trash service. Just imagine the smell of rotten food, feces, and other unpleasantness as you walk through the halls to get to your apartment. Some days are worse than others. I almost puked multiple times. Quite embarrassing when you invite guest over. 2. Loft rooms- The bedroom walls don't go all the way to the roof. I knew this fact coming into the apartment, so I was slightly more prepared to deal with the noise. However, I recommend that you are absolutely positive that you are willing to live under these circumstances because you can hear everything your roommate does. I mean EVERYTHING! 3. Thin walls- Particularly Thurs-Sat, you often hear people (likely Duke undergrads) in the middle of night getting back from a bibulous time. I work in the morning, so my Friday mornings were a bit brutal. 4. Mold- I live in an older building at WV. The windows facing the outside were extremely moldy. Gross. We did our best to keep it clean, but it kept coming back. 5. Security guards- The leasing staff is friendly, but some of the security guards are rude. On an occasion, I overheard the guards sharing private info (more like talking crap) with each other about some of the tenants. Also, if you ask them for any assistance, you sometimes get a condescending response. 6. Parking- The availability of parking has shrunk considerably since I moved in. For instance, the gravel lot was reduced by about half (Duke reserved the other spots). Also, you can no longer park on Fernway St for more than 2 hours. WV is building a new complex, so unless they make more parking space, good luck finding a spot. Pros: 1. Location- Can't beat the location. In middle of Downtown Durham, you have access to restaurants, bars, American Tobacco, etc. 2. Amenities- Nice gym, pool, BBQ areas, business center. 3. Maintenance- The staff responded quickly to my maintenance issues.

Background: I'm a Duke graduate student/young professional living in a 2BR apartment at West Village. Cons: 1. Smelly halls- At West Village, we must pay for trash service. Just imagine the smell of rotten food, feces, and other unpleasantness as you walk through the halls to get to your apartment. Some days are worse than others. I almost puked multiple times. Quite embarrassing when you invite guest over. 2. Loft rooms- The bedroom walls don't go all the way to the roof. I knew this fact coming into the apartment, so I was slightly more prepared to deal with the noise. However, I recommend that you are absolutely positive that you are willing to live under these circumstances because you can hear everything your roommate does. I mean EVERYTHING! 3. Thin walls- Particularly Thurs-Sat, you often hear people (likely Duke undergrads) in the middle of night getting back from a bibulous time. I work in the morning, so my Friday mornings were a bit brutal. 4. Mold- I live in an older building at WV. The windows facing the outside were extremely moldy. Gross. We did our best to keep it clean, but it kept coming back. 5. Security guards- The leasing staff is friendly, but some of the security guards are rude. On an occasion, I overheard the guards sharing private info (more like talking crap) with each other about some of the tenants. Also, if you ask them for any assistance, you sometimes get a condescending response. 6. Parking- The availability of parking has shrunk considerably since I moved in. For instance, the gravel lot was reduced by about half (Duke reserved the other spots). Also, you can no longer park on Fernway St for more than 2 hours. WV is building a new complex, so unless they make more parking space, good luck finding a spot. Pros: 1. Location- Can't beat the location. In middle of Downtown Durham, you have access to restaurants, bars, American Tobacco, etc. 2. Amenities- Nice gym, pool, BBQ areas, business center. 3. Maintenance- The staff responded quickly to my maintenance issues. Read less

2013 - 2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/02/2014
I've lived in several apartments, and even though West Village is a nice apartment in regards to features, amenities, etc. there are many frustrations to living at West Village. The maintenance staff is extremely nice and helpful but that is once they arrive to fix the problem. Often it takes a while and a couple phone calls for them to arrive. Yet, the biggest problem of it all is the management. They are defensive and not willing to be of help. For instance, I had water damage not once but 3 times, and maintenance was aware of the problem from the start and it was never fully fixed. So on the third time, I had to plead with the management just to replace my carpet in my room which was soaked. It has been extremely frustrating to have to beg with management just to maintain my apartment in the state that I originally got it.

Resident
2013 - 2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/27/2014
Living in West Village is a luxurious experience. At a similar price point to apartment communities in the area, it is not comparable in terms of comfort in quality - much nicer. 3 blocks from center city and 1 block from bright leaf square, great pool/courtyard area and fantastic gym. The unit vary widely in terms of spaciousness and visual appeal, but the price of rent fairly reflects that. If you go for one of the upper-tier apartments in terms of price, you will not be disappointed. I'm in the old cigarette factory building, which is the closet of all buildings in west village to the train tracks. Trains go by 5-10 times a day and it does get loud, but in my opinion it's a non-issue. Trash pick-up is extremely convenient right outside your apartment door, and the staff in general is extremely kind and helpful. I would strongly recommend anyone looking for an apartment in this location and price range to check this place out. I've been here for 3 months and it's been nothing but a positive experience.

The maintenance team is very responsive to service requests. The grounds are well taken care of. The apartment complex is pet friendly, having multiple relief stations with pet waste bags available. Valet trash and recycling. Newly renovated, expansive workout facility. It can be hard to find parking on Friday and Saturday evenings but I know they're working on this. Resident
2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/07/2014
I recently moved into a 2 bedroom, loft apartment in one of the old Tobacco warehouse buildings that have been converted. So far my experience here has been excellent. I love the apartment layout, and the combination of the skylight and very large (old warehouse sized) front windows let in a great deal of light. The apartment is surprisingly quiet, I very occasionally hear my neighbors or a train whistle (we are right next to the Durham train station), but this is probably the quietest apartment I've ever lived in. The staff is outstanding. My furniture was delivered on a Saturday, and one of the staff members came in a early to make sure the gate was open for the Atlas Van Lines semi to pull into the court yard to deliver my furniture. The kitchen is beautiful, if a bit small, with marble countertops and stainless appliances. So far, the neighbors I've met are also quite friendly. I'm pretty happy with my decision to move in here!

Resident
2011 - 2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/07/2014
I have been living in one of the older buildings - Phase 1 of West Village - for over 3 years now and I love it. The warehouse feel of it, the openness and all the wonderful natural lighting is hard to find any where else in downtown Durham. The rent is pricey but it's worth it to be in walking distance of so many great restaurants, bars, art galleries, Central Park and the Farmer's Market. They are very pet friendly and, for the most part, the other residents are mainly professional or grad students. Not much "student" housing going on here, which I prefer. If you are considering living in or close to downtown Durham you should come see what West Village has to offer.

Resident
2012 - 2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/06/2014
I haven't been in very many apartments that are more beautiful than WV. The ceilings are 20 feet high and made of salvaged wood from the tobacco days, and lots of big windows w/ natural light. In terms of aesthetics, this is tough to match. The management has been responsive and helpful to me over the last several years. I moved internally from one apartment into a larger one, and they worked with me to optimize my living situation and make it a seamless transfer. They've continued to be proactive in responding to any issues that I've raised, and they are very friendly and welcoming. The maintenance team is top notch too. They get things fixed usually the same day that I file maintenance requests, and they are genuinely nice people. With the construction of a new building under way, the parking situation is more challenging, especially for visiting guests who don't have parking passes. Sometimes they have to park 2-3 blocks away and walk. Residents have the option of parking in the deck for free while the construction is on though. Not too many options for further remedy, until the new building is completed and that deck is made available. I recommend WV -- I've recruited a few friends to come live here. I'm sure I'll be here for years to follow.

Report
Resident
2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/18/2013
West Village would be a great place to live, were it not for the terrible management company. We've lived here several years, and generally like our apartment. The closets are a bit small and the appliances aren't great, but the hardwood floors and high ceilings are nice. The location is good, as well. About a year and a half ago, however, Bell Partners took over as the property management company. Since then, it seems like every week brings a new headache. Parking is horrible: they demolished a parking lot that accounted for 2/3rds of the overall available spaces in order to build more apartments. They supposedly implemented a new parking policy, but it's never enforced. If you arrive after 6pm, you'll probably have to park across the street in a poorly lit gravel lot where several robberies have occurred in the past 6 weeks. The other option is to pay $30 a month to park in a parking garage. Whatever "rent" amount you are quoted by the front office, be sure to add at least $50 to account for various fees. Residents are forced to pay $30 per month for basic cable, without any ability to opt-out (not including internet or anything). You'll also have to pay $20 per month for a trash pick up service. This would be mildly convenient if the hallways didn't reek of rotten produce most of the time. Also, if you plan on getting a pet, expect to pay $300 up front (which I believe is a fee, not a deposit) PLUS a monthly fee per pet. Safety is also an issue, and for some reason the management doesn't seem terribly concerned. It's not that I'd expect the management to prevent every little thing from happening, but they could at least let residents know that they should be concerned. As I mentioned, there have been several armed robberies in recent weeks. How do I know that? Other residents had to tell me, because the front office didn't bother to alert anyone. For some reason they send ~3 emails per week about random social events, but they're unwilling to alert residents about safety issues that actually matter. If I were you, I'd rent elsewhere.

2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/03/2013
I have lived at West Village for 2 years. I have transferred from a small one bedroom into a big two bedroom apartment (with a different lease term and rate of course.) The leasing staff was helpful and understanding that my family was growing and that I needed more space and helped me by making the transfer process quick and easy. Yes there is an issue with parking but a new building is going up, have some patience! Durham is growing and I love to see that my home is a part of it. I do pay the extra $35 a month for parking and it is not as bad as people here make it sound. I got covered parking and I do not have to walk farther than a block to get to my apartment. I've got a WD in my apartment which I know many people do not have but you get what you pay for. Anywat, I guess all thst I want to say is that West Village is way better than many places around. I was shopping around 2 years ago and I do not regret choosing West Village.

Is West Village Perfect? No. Is West Village a good place to live? Yes. I have just moved into the community and I must say that out of all places that I have seen in Durham, this is by far the best option. Did construction and lack of free parking make me think harder if I want to live there? Yes, but I have decided to move in and so far I had no issues. I would say that you should think about West Village really hard if you are looking to move to Durham. The staff is nice and I am always greeted with a smile.

Resident
2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/30/2013
My experience at West Villages has been sub-par at best. Albeit the location can't be beat, paying close to $1100 for 800 square feet should result in less headaches than I've had during my short time here (10 months). Besides the thin walls, where every high heel and cough (my neighbor once said 'bless you' to me) can be heard, the constant outside door issues (electronic lock broken, door jammed), the constant construction, and the lack of parking available nearby (that doesn't cost an additional $35), the service quality has been the most frustrating aspect of my time here. I've had several service calls, which is understandable, and for the most part, not one of my voice messages have been returned. To have a service call initiated, each case required a physical office visit. During the last visit, maintenance locked me out of my apartment. Ok, company policy to lock for liability reasons - no problem, but shouldn't I be aware that you even entered my apartment or locked the door while I was in the courtyard reading? I simple phone call would suffice. Need a key made? Sure, no problem, we'll call you back...nope, they didn't. I received a call from my bud to ask why I never got in touch about the package he sent me...well bud, the reason why is because West Villages held onto it for 3 months without so much as a phone call, email, or note. There may be safety issues (judging from the notes and emails received), but welcome to Durham - can't really hold West Villages liable for that as they have a security officer and keep the place locked up. Lastly, there's the constant debris falling off my brick walls and the one-time water leak that damaged a painting and my sofa - this isn't common in West Villages from what I understand, but note that the renter's insurance you're required to have is to cover West's liability during guests accidents or falls, not to replace your damaged property.

Granted, there is a lot of constructions that is happening and one or two parking lots are gone right now. Resident
2008 - 2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/18/2013
We moved here 5 years ago, and fell in love with the complex. We've always lived in "Phase 2" - first in Cobb, and now in OCF. We were able to break our lease when we were in Cobb and I was laid off, a few years ago, and sign a new lease in OCF, we were grateful at the time to the management company. While we loved our Cobb apartment, we did have a few, but bearable, inconveniences. Since moving across the street to OCF, West Village changed management companies. The new management company has been absolutely horrible. I've been waiting 2 days to have a simple lightbulb changed (I'd do it myself but don't have a tall enough ladder to reach the bulb). The old gym was closed before the new gym has yet to open, and, there isn't any date when it will open, but we've been hearing for over a month that new gym is "coming soon". A new parking permit policy was put into place but isn't enforced. They've shut down a big parking lot in front of the O'Brien building in order to build a "Phase 3" building, however we've been told it will still be "a few weeks" before any parking enforcement in other other lots is actually accomplished. So after a long day at work, I might get a spot in the lot, even with my "resident sticker". When I asked about when the parking "enforcement" was first to go into effect, the young woman in the office simply stated "we've sent out a lot of emails" - but I had to ASK QUESTIONS in order to find out that there'd be 3-hour parking for business customers, or that there wouldn't be any guest parking for residents - none of that was communicated, but the office staff was short and rude about it. You're also required to pay for "valet trash" - without an option to opt-out. We live across the hall from the trash chute; we're perfectly capable of taking out our own trash, yet are forced to pay $25/month for someone else to take it from outside our door, and only 5 days a week, not even weekends!! Additionally, now between 6 and 9pm, the hallways are filled with residents' black trash bins, and the hallways smell! Our rent has also gone up over 30% this year. After arguing with the management, we were able to knock that down a bit; after all, we've lived here for over 4 years without such a drastic increase. Even though it was higher than we would have liked, we decided to stay as we're likely moving out of state next year and didn't want to move somewhere else in Durham for just one year. The walls can seem thin at times, but from what I've heard, "Phase 1" is much worse. I've knocked on upstairs or next door neighbors doors and asked them to turn a TV or music down, on occasion, and people are generally amicable about it - after all, we're all in the same situation.

Resident
2010 - 2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/11/2013
I moved here a few years ago due to excellent downtown location and modern interiors and amenities. It was nice enough at first (albeit overpriced), but new management has made living here one headache and hassle after another. The new management seems to be concerned with profits and new development at the expense of existing residents' quality of life. They blast out emails with unreasonable last-minute notifications (e.g., car needs to be moved tomorrow to repave, new waiver needs to be signed immediately), not taking into consideration that some of their residents may be traveling or otherwise unable to immediately meet their last-minute demands. They closed the old gym at a moments notice in preparation for an (unnecessary) new gym that may open "sometime next week" - they should be able to make the shift immediately or keep the old gym partially operational in the meantime rather than deny residents this key amenity without advance notice. Perhaps most vexing is that they have just closed a major residents' parking lot to make way for construction of a new apartment building - with no coherent plan for where all of those cars should now be parked (unless you want to pay extra to park in the garage). Not to mention that it is not the safest neighborhood to be walking around in after dark if you have to park relatively far away due to the new restrictions. I have complained to management but they seem to have no real concern for the inconveniences and hassles that they are imposing on their residents. As others have noted, on top of all of this they are significantly raising rent! I will move out as soon as my lease is up. It is not worth the high price or frustration with new management's policies and operations.

Resident
2010 - 2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/07/2013
I have lived at West Village for two years and have just recently given my notice to moved out due to my job transfer. I live in the Cobb building which was renovated in 2008. I only have a problem with noise on occasional evenings, usually my neighbor is out walking her dog and her daughter gets excited and loud, which only lasts a few minutes. I hate to leave West Village! It has been a great experience. The staff is always so nice and very helpful. Maintenance is always very quick to respond to any work orders and the location is amazing! I am able to walk to most of my favorite local hang outs and my friends are always commenting on how beautiful my apartment is! Parking has gotten a little tough since they will be using one of the lots to build a brand new building. They do offer covered parking in the parking garage right next door to my building. It is a very reasonable price so I have purchased one and have not had any issues with parking. I plan to visit Durham often after my move so I am looking forward to seeing the new building and all that it has to offer! West Village has been renovating tons of stuff since the new management company took over a year or so ago. We are getting a new gym, I've noticed new furniture and their new leasing office is gorgeous! I would definitely recommend West Village if you love the downtown feel, saving gas and loving where you live!

Resident
2012 - 2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/06/2013
The building I'm in is part of phase II and I don't suffer the noise issues that others in some of the earlier buildings do. Location is awesome. Parking is a joke. I'm no longer allowed to park near the entrance to my apartment because that lot is now reserved for local businesses who rent from WV. Instead I need to park way out back and fight for a spot with the overflow from the patrons of local restaurants. It seems WV is more concerned about catering to the folks coming into town for a $20 meal over those providing a guaranteed income upwards of 1700 dollars a month. Lighting around the building goes on and off (I assume to conserve energy), but as someone who walks their dogs at night, its very apparent that oftentimes many of the lights are out at the same time, so they might as well not even be there. Security is an issue as well. The gates to the courtyard are often unlocked and open to the public as are the double doors on the rear of the building and in the courtyard. Grounds are kept very nice. They spend a lot of money on landscaping. Interior areas are a little run down. Hall carpet is dirty and worn. Paint in halls is worn. To the left of the mailboxes there are sloppy patches of spackle that have been there since I moved in last July. Lower level of apartment gets damp when it rains and walls seep moisture. Brick walls are black with mold and calcium leaching. It's a dramatic space and a great location, and there are some nice amenities such as the pool, and fitness center, but the lack of parking and lack of upkeep makes me think my money could be better spent elsewhere.

2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/01/2013
The major problem with West Village is there is nothing like them in the area. They really don't have to compete since there aren't any other mid to high end apartments in Durham. These apartments just aren't worth the cost. We are renting in the old buildings. The fact that these apartments cost over $1000 a month and don't have in unit laundry is mind boggling. At first we thought we could live without this but since the laundry room often has two or more washers and dryers broken it causes a major issue. The fixtures are very low end. Probably the lowest of the three apartments we have lived in in the Triangle. The only thing these apartments have going for them is looks and location. We probably would have stayed but when it was time to resign the rent was going to go up $200! These apartments are definitely not worth that. Resident
2011 - 2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/27/2013
I'm really not sure why so many people are complaining about West Village. Is it perfect? No, but I absolutely love it here, and the only reason I'm moving out is I'm leaving the state. Yes, the rent is high. Get over it. The apartments are gorgeous. Ridiculously high ceilings, granite countertops, stainless steel appliances, beautiful floors, and enormous windows. I do get the feeling the contractor fell asleep when designing the bathrooms but oh well. I will probably never again live in a building as cool as this one and will miss my apt terribly. The noise is *occasionally* a problem. I live in the newer phase II building Cobb, so I think we have much less noise problems than the phase I buildings. That being said, I do hear my neighbors having sex and used to hear them playing board games like I was in the room. This only applies to one side of my apartment though. I *never* hear the neighbors on the other side. Who knows why. Once in a while I'll hear the people above walking around but not much more than that. For the most part though, it is quiet. I have found everything clean, and the small gym is great and adequate for me, especially with the free wifi. Yes, there was recently a changeover in management. I haven't noticed anything all that different frankly. Tons of free parking in the lot, but I pay $35 a month for the garage because I'm paranoid. I believe most of the newer units come with W/D inside the apartments. Very dog friendly community. I can't say anything about the pool because I've never been in it. The fireplace is fake but still fun to turn on. Tons of natural light, even from having only one window (albeit, a very large one). I love the floor plan, long like you would find in SF, with no direct ceiling on the bedroom. I love this place. Perhaps it's overpriced, but you won't find much else like it. Very unique converted tobacco warehouse. Maintenance is generally pretty good. Occasional noise would be my only complaint. Highly recommend this place if you're looking for a different living experience and have the money to pay for it. Can't comment on how they handle when you move out yet.
I'm really not sure why so many people are complaining about West Village. Is it perfect? No, but I absolutely love it here, and the only reason I'm moving out is I'm leaving the state. Yes, the rent is high. Get over it. The apartments are gorgeous. Ridiculously high ceilings, granite countertops, stainless steel appliances, beautiful floors, and enormous windows. I do get the feeling the contractor fell asleep when designing the bathrooms but oh well. I will probably never again live in a building as cool as this one and will miss my apt terribly. The noise is *occasionally* a problem. I live in the newer phase II building Cobb, so I think we have much less noise problems than the phase I buildings. That being said, I do hear my neighbors having sex and used to hear them playing board games like I was in the room. This only applies to one side of my apartment though. I *never* hear the neighbors on the other side. Who knows why. Once in a while I'll hear the people above walking around but not much more than that. For the most part though, it is quiet. I have found everything clean, and the small gym is great and adequate for me, especially with the free wifi. Yes, there was recently a changeover in management. I haven't noticed anything all that different frankly. Tons of free parking in the lot, but I pay $35 a month for the garage because I'm paranoid. I believe most of the newer units come with W/D inside the apartments. Very dog friendly community. I can't say anything about the pool because I've never been in it. The fireplace is fake but still fun to turn on. Tons of natural light, even from having only one window (albeit, a very large one). I love the floor plan, long like you would find in SF, with no direct ceiling on the bedroom. I love this place. Perhaps it's overpriced, but you won't find much else like it. Very unique converted tobacco warehouse. Maintenance is generally pretty good. Occasional noise would be my only complaint. Highly recommend this place if you're looking for a different living experience and have the money to pay for it. Can't comment on how they handle when you move out yet. Read less

2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/27/2013
West Village is a great community. We moved here from Kansas a little over a month ago. I work in downtown Durham so I am able to walk there every morning which is very convenient. My wife is able to have the car during the day. We have a two bedroom in the Cobb building and absolutely love the apartment. The staff is is great and we just recently attended our first "resident get together" that West Village hosts once a month. It was fun and we were able to meet more people in the West Village community. We have not yet had to call maintenance for any issues but our neighbors have told us that the maintenance team here is very quick and efficient. My wife loves that the security is so high. There are codes to get into all gates and buildings as well as a patrol officer after hours. I would definitely recommend West Village to anyone moving to the area.

Resident
2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 11/06/2012
West Village has only two things going for them - Location and Loft. The apartments are in fact beautiful, with exposed brick, high ceilings and lots of space. But everything else is so awful, I can't imagine recommending anyone move into this place. The worst part about the apartments is the noise. I'm sitting here writing this, and I can hear my upstairs neighbor's entire conversation. When they watch TV, it's like I'm watching their TV. When they walk down the hall, I sometimes wonder if someone is in my apartment. The company who turned this building into apartments did NOTHING to control for noise, and it's obvious. You hear your neighbors dog, you hear their screaming child, you hear EVERYTHING. It honestly makes you feel crazy. For what you pay here, it's just not acceptable to have to deal with the noise. The developers really missed out on an opportunity to make these livable. Instead they just churn people in and out after 1 year because no one wants to renew their lease. Secondly, the leasing office has continued to disappoint me. They play favorites with residents, (meaning they let some residents get away with having pets without paying fees, and then are unsympathetic to other residents requests) are surprisingly uneducated about the property and basic questions like "Can I pay my rent online" often end with incorrect answers. They always tell you they'll look into something. And never do. There is one woman in the office who I trust for answers, but other than that, they're all incompetent. Their handyman is amazing. Seriously, they need to keep that guy b/c he's really all they got going for them. He fixes things immediately. And usually leaves a nice note on your counter. Front leasing office should learn from him. I wrote this after a long few months of thinking about moving out, and want to warn ANYONE thinking about moving into West Village. Don't do it. You'll be surrounded by a bunch of Duke Undergrads, you'll have to deal with awful noise, and you'll be forced to deal with a completely useless front office.

Resident
2011 - 2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/22/2012
I leased a one bedroom apartment from West Village for one year, and moved out a little over a month ago. The question of whether or not I would recommend this complex to others is mostly dependent upon what you want out of your home. I personally would not however had renewed my lease if I was going to stay in the area (I ended up moving out of the state). Pros: -- Great Location - If you are in need to be close to Duke or love the nightlife, this is a great location. The university is close by and there are plenty of restaurants and bars within walking distance. -- Great Visuals - The complex is a series of old warehouses used to store and roll tobacco (don t worry, there's no lingering smell). The apartments have exposed wood and steel beams which really make the place stand out. -- Upscale amenities - In my apartment I had all stainless steel appliances, wood floors, granite counter tops, and washer/dryer in the unit. These features however do cost a pretty penny to have. -- Maintenance and Office Staff - Any maintenance requests I had were always completed in a timely manner and the staff were friendly. In addition the office staff were friendly and knew me by name. -- Security - While no setup is ever perfect, I always felt quite safe in the building. Depending on where you entered in the building you would have to pass through one to three locked doors needing either a code or card to gain entry. Cons: -- Noise - They really should have spent more money on noise isolation when they divided the buildings into apartments. You can easily hear your neighbors having conversations and doing their daily routines in the apartments next to you. It is said that phase one is worse than phase two, however I lived in phase two so it must be really bad over in phase one. Additionally you can hear the neighbors above walking around due to the way the building was originally built. This can become quite maddening at times. -- Cost - Due to the location and amenities offered you will pay a premium price to live here. For me I didn t consider it worth the cost in the end, but some may disagree if the location means a lot to them. -- Gym Equipment - The times that I used the gym, there were always machines that were broken or otherwise worn out. However, the machines that did work worked fine for my use and it was never crowded. -- Return of Security Deposit - The managing company did not send out my security deposit within the 30 day window required by law. I had sent them an email regarding the missing refund, however they did not reply to my message. I then received the check for the refund the next week, coincidentally postmarked two days after I had sent them the email asking it s status. They did however refund the full amount that was owed and I didn t need to take things further. Other thoughts: The management changed in early 2012 however I didn t see much of a difference in quality other than the changing of some of the office staff. I see some people on here complaining that it went downhill, however I didn t notice that. I can t comment on the pool as I never tried it; It was closed shortly after I moved in for the winter and I otherwise just never got around to it. As for parking, I didn t have any issues due to the times I came and went, however if you arrive in the late evenings on the weekends it may be difficult to find an open parking space. This is due to the parking lot being used by visitors to the downtown area. As I said previously, while I wouldn t have stayed here another year personally, it is possible others may see it as a good value due to its amenities and location. I recommend you do all of the research yourself and check out their apartments before deciding for, or against West Village.

2011 - 2012 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/07/2012
West Village has been my home for the last year. I have been here through the change in management and I see why things have changed. Usually, if a change happens, that means the previous company is doing something wrong and the new company is brought in to change this for the better. We, residents can do more things electronically, like pay rent, sign leases and when we do these things, we save paper. The new company is getting to know West Village and I see it getting cleaner and more organized. Change is not easy and I know that a lot of my neighbors are upset because they do not see the same people in the office that they were used to. Policies have changed, faces have changes, and maintenance guys are new. Rick, the supervisor is wonderful. He makes sure that we all get taken care of and I like that a lot. The company that cleans the property is the same, so I am not sure why others are writing about the property not being cleaned. It is clean. I love West Village s character with the exposed brick and beams. I love the courtyards and grilling areas. Location is super! I walk to work and after work I come home and get a glass of wine from the West End bar. Life is good. I would recommend moving to West Village. Change is good and the new team will make things better, it just takes some time.

Report
Resident
2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/22/2012
In short? Don't bother renting from West Village, unless you only use your apartment for sleeping at night, and you're away on the weekends. Best for Duke Graduate students who want something on the bus line, and will be spending so much time doing research on campus that the building issues won't be a worry. Overpriced for what you're getting, especially since the new management came on board and stopped the standard upkeep & perks that were provided by previous managers. Don't usually post reviews but I've been so disappointed here that I'll be posting this review on every West Village review I can find. In full? -Noise transference is the absolute biggest issue across all the different apartment buildings - Phase one and Phase two. From any point in your apartment, upstairs or downstairs if you have a loft, you WILL easily hear your neighbours going about their business in their homes, loud music playing, people talking loudly in all the corridors, etc. Not a problem if you have a quiet neighbour but it easily becomes a problem when pet owners congregate in the hall with their pets or the college kids have a hangout which spills into the corridors. Which tends to happen frequently, especially closer to the weekends. Noise transference also comes in pretty easily from the streets, as well so you hear people talking loudly on their cells as they walk, you hear people hanging out at night... -The pet owners... They can be quite insensitive to the needs of others, and for some reason, West Village seems to be overrun with multiple large dogs per apartment, and small yappy dogs. Makes for a lot of dog noises on a daily basis. I've seen/smelled dog pee and feces in the inside hallway carpets, and owners often forget to pick up behind their pets outdoors, leading to lots of flies in the grass outside the apartment windows during the summer. Pet owners sometimes walk their dogs indoors, which leads to a lot of noisy barking and dog-running at all hours of the day/night. They also leave their dogs cooped up inside these tiny apartments for long hours which makes the dogs restless and you can hear them galloping through the apartments overhead. Very annoying when it happens - frequently - at 6 in the morning. - Parking tends to be a nightmare every evening, since it is on a first come basis. There are ample parking spaces around each building, but since West Village seems to share the tenant parking with Durham at large, expect to return home from work at 5:00pm and park in the street, at the very edge of the parking lot (far away from the housing entrances) or even a block away. Spaces that should be reserved for paying West Village tenants tend to be filled up by Durham diners and Amtrack users between 5-10pm most days of the week. - Safety is also a HUGE issue in downtown Durham. The factory style buildings are opened out to the public on all sides, so although one has to have a buzz card to actually enter the apartments, it's extremely easy for pan-handlers to loiter around the building and eventually sneak in with a tenant or hop the wall by the pool and hang around outside until the doors are open. Sounds far-fetched, but it has happened too many times to count and tenants often have to call the police to get the panhandlers out of the buildings. Furthermore, the beggars and drifters will target tenants as they enter the buildings or walk to their cars - West Village has little by the way of privacy and is too open to the streets. - The apartment themselves are nice enough, but only in the Phase Two buildings, where there are bamboo floors, nice fixtures, etc. However, beware that these are 'old' warehouses - they do carry a very musty smell that doesn't really go away. Also, the walls and exposed beams tend to be quite moldy and presents breathing problems, if you have a reasonably sensitive respiratory system. In the changing weather months, expect to get a few crawlies coming out of cracks in the thick walls or the wood beams...
In short? Don't bother renting from West Village, unless you only use your apartment for sleeping at night, and you're away on the weekends. Best for Duke Graduate students who want something on the bus line, and will be spending so much time doing research on campus that the building issues won't be a worry. anonymous 08/03/2012

In complete agreement with you, anonymous. I, too, have been living in West Village for several years, and find the new management absolutely unbearable and inefficient. Bell Properties, the new management, seems to be populated by cretins. It took MONTHS for the new management to actually introduce themselves to their tenants. The complex remains filthy. And clean carpets are nothing but a memory of the "golden years" when the old management was truly in charge. This is, of course, quite alarming and glaring, given all the canines that live in West Village. The rugs smell. I hate to think of a possible flea infestation in the hallways, particularly during the summer. Plus they stupidly want to get rid of the "free zone," which fosters, at one level or another, the notion of community living and good neighborly relations. The new management also bombards tenants with the most banal emails, trying to pass these dumb missives as "neighborly" relations. They should spent their time and energy actually improving the place and valuing tenants who have been living here and making this space a home. The great thing about West Village, I always thought, was the diversity of professionals as well as the different age ranges. It appears that the new management privileges the undergraduate population, and is primarily invested in making this place a glorified dorm. Sadly, I have seen a mass exodus of professionals since this new management took over, and I will soon be one of those taking my rental money elsewhere.

Resident
2011 - 2012 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/04/2012
I've been living here in the Toms building since Summer 2011. Management has been great. Very accommodating and friendly. I also have no complaints about people on my floor and my direct neighbors. People have been in general pretty quiet and the "thin walls" haven't been much of an issue. It's just that... well... the reuse of this old tobacco warehouse is great and all, but the apartment floor-plans seem to be a bit poorly executed. The space doesn't feel like it's being used to its potential. It feels inefficient. The unit is a long narrow strip with one tiny window and a 3x3 square sun window. I like large windows, I love sunlight, and unfortunately, this place is too dark for my taste. Some friends live over in the Hicks building and their floor-plan was created in a much more efficient way. Not as narrow, more "squat," the floor-plan at hicks overall feels like more of an open space as opposed to a narrow hall. I might add, I do love the fact I haven't had to turn on my heater ONCE this Winter. Stay's pretty warm and cozy in the Toms building. (Good thing too, cause the ceilings are high enough to make heating the area a nightmare.) With that said, it's in a great location where you can walk to all kinds of different businesses that'll keep ya fed, keep ya drunk, and keep ya entertained. Check it out, decide for yourself, and please... ask to see as many floor-plan variations as you can. They are definitely not all the same. Good luck!

Resident
2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/01/2011
I sublease an apartment at West Village. About a week after moving in, I was fast asleep one night, probably dreaming about David Beckham or cheesecake, and was suddenly startled awake at 2am by what can only be described as the unmistakable sounds of some girl getting boned next door. No lie, I thought someone was in my bedroom -- it was THAT loud. I think the builders must have put a sheet of drywall between the two places and that s about it. The sound carries so well, in fact, that I can distinctly hear the play-by-play of every sexual encounter this dude has -- and worst of all, I can't escape it. All I can do is lay in bed with a pillow over my head trying to block out the sounds of unadulterated, albeit abbreviated passion. I'd say my neighbor must be a total stud because he gets laid all of the time, but my saving grace is that his exploits only last about three minutes and then end abruptly (which is why, I can only assume, he always has a different girl). Another bonus of his decided non-studliness is that I never have to hear any of his conquests, well . . . finish. I d have probably moved out by now if I had to be subjected to that as well. After all, there is nothing worse than being jarred awake in the dead of night only to lie in bed, alone with your cats, watching with bloodshot eyes as the bright red numbers of your digital alarm clock tick away while you are forced to endure the echoes of ecstasy being had by someone else. My one consolation is knowing that it ain t that great. And -- Joe Neighbor, if I may take the liberty of answering your routine post-coital query on behalf of the chick in your bed who is trying so diligently to mask her profound disappointment: No, it wasn t as good for her as it was for you. But aside from the penetrating sound issues (pun kind of intended), West Village is a really cool complex with friendly staff, nice (however rabidly horny) residents, etc. Also, the new Durham rocks, and the location of this place is awesome. Nevertheless, none of this outweighs the noise factor. This is something I simply cannot bear, and so I am moving out in a few weeks -- and unfortunately, some other poor, unsuspecting soul who moves into my place is going to have to suffer through the resonating pleasure proclamations of his/her new neighbors regular rendezvous. Good luck with that.

Resident
2011 Recommended Property Reviewed 07/10/2011
I'm just sitting here listening to my neighbors music which made me want to write a review. I've been living here in West Village for about 6 weeks now and I can't wait to move. The management has been extremely accommodating, helpful and friendly. I have no complaints about them. The complex is very secure and I always feel safe here. The grounds are very well kept and the gym and pool are very nice. The other tenants are friendly, mature, and generally respectful. And the location is obviously great. My only real complaints are with the apartments themselves. I simply don't like them. I live in a one bedroom which is long and tunnel-like with one tiny window at the end. The majority of the apartment gets no natural light and is generally cave-like. The noise is borderline ridiculous. The only saving grace is, like I mentioned, the tenants are pretty mature and respectful. Any music playing, tv watching, phone conversations can be heard as though they're taking place in my apartment. The girl above me's alarm clock wakes me up every morning even though I have a loud fan sitting right next to my head. It's not a bad place to live, just know what you're getting yourself into... Once the novelty of the exposed brick walls, thirty foot ceilings and bamboo floors wears off you're left with a dark and loud apartment.

Resident
2009 - 2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/18/2011
I've lived in West Village apartments for 2 years. When I first moved in, I was enamored by the high ceilings, exposed brick loft-style apartments. However, think carefully and consider your other options before signing with West Village: 1. The leasing office management is terrible. On the surface they seem like sweet ladies, but they are unaccommodating sharks who do nothing for the tenant and everything to turn their own profit. They pretend to care about the tenants when in reality they are inflexible, apathetic, and unorganized. They did not understand the concept of following through on an issue and it would often take me and my roommate multiple attempts (and speaking with multiple people) to get an issue resolved. 2. The sound insulation is unbearable. I could hear not only my upstairs neighbors' every step, but also my downstairs neighbors talking, and people in the hallways and stairwells. If your neighbor has a pet or a party, it will sound like it's in your own apartment. I don't sleep or wake particularly early, but still it was unbearable. They will tell you only Phase I has this issue, but you can hear your neighbors play music and walk around in Phase II apartments as well. 3. The amenities are nothing compared to what you could get at Station 9, the Lofts, or Trinity Commons. There is a gym but it's tiny and old and has very limited machines (compared to Station 9 which has new equipment and an indoor a basketball court). The pool is also very small. The conference room has 5 computers, only 2 of which work. They also started charging for coffee this year -- not a single other apartment complex in the area does that. All in all, you get what you pay for. Actually, you get a little less than you pay for. The individual apartments are nice, but prepare to hear a lot of noise/get a lot of noise complaints. The maintenance guys are helpful, but the leasing office is incompetent, unorganized, and selfish. Don't live here if you're a family or a college student who wants to have parties occasionally, or if you expect comprehensive service from the leasing management. For the same price range, go with Station 9 or the new Trinity Commons instead.
