Report
Resident
2009 - 2010 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/18/2010
lived here my senior year (wanted to get away from the "fratty" feel a lot of complexes around duke have). was a great experience. the apartment (in the COBB building) was fantastic, two bedroom two bath with walls to the ceiling (watch out, some apartments are in the "loft style" so on some of the bedrooms the walls don't go up to the ceiling. not as much privacy if you're sharing an apartment). plenty of room, loved the high ceilings, granite countertops, excellent appliances. for such a big apartment (around 1100 sq. ft.) utilities were fairly cheap (around $120 a month for electric and water) the apartments are all renovated warehouses, and my roommate and I loved having two brick walls in our living room. however, you have to give up a little to get the cool old warehouse feel - dirt sometimes falls off the walls (when we moved our couch against the brick wall the back was always covered in dust), and the ventilation system goes from apartment to apartment, so I had a very easy time hearing everything that was happening with my neighbor (my roommate, however, didn't hear a thing, so must depend on where your vent actually goes). rain is also pretty loud on the rooftop because it's flat. I loved this, but others may not. staff was incredibly friendly, very helpful and very laid back. always said hi when you saw them around. my roommate went out of town for a while and forgot to pay her garage parking, they were very nice about it, no late fees or anything. maintenance was fairly prompt, although takes a few days for a request. the ceilings are VERY high so unless you have a ladder, you can't change the light bulbs yourself, which gets annoying because the fans are always shaking them loose. maintenance will fix them for you, but you have to wait, and our apartment had no windows in the bedrooms = very dark for a day or two. lots of free parking, however if you get there late on a weeknight during the year, you may have to park far away or "make up" your own space. never had a problem with towing when this happened, and other tenants are respectful and don't box others in. they said they had an after hours courtesy patrol if you felt unsafe walking around. I never had to use it, but it was nice to know it was there because muggings do occur occassionally in the area. never heard about one happening actually at the complex, but a few blocks away. my apartments required two key card swipes to enter, so I always felt safe in that respect. overall a wonderful experience. really cool apartments and really great people. highly recommended.

Resident
2008 - 2010 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/01/2010
West Village is in an ideal location, within walking distance of many downtown shops, restaurants, and bars, as well as to Duke University campus and library. The Flowers building has hardwood floors, high ceilings and lots of light from the huge windows. Noise is the biggest issue, it just depends on the neighbors. The gym, business center, and pool are convenient. The best aspect of the grounds are the communal picnic areas with gas grills - I spend several evenings a week parked there during the summer with other residents and friends. The best part about West Village is the people. The folks in the office go out of their way to get to know the residents, checking in with them regularly. They respond quickly and professionally to complaints. They organize great holiday parties and other activities to try to form community among other residents - like book clubs, pick up soccer and basketball games, pet play dates on the lawn, summer outdoor concerts, and more. I'm thankful for all of their efforts to build a healthy and happy community here.

Resident
2008 - 2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/01/2010
Okay, so Durham isn't exactly the mecca of amazing apartments, so there are limited options. But if you're looking for safe urban living, West Village is an excellent place to be. The newer apartments (Phase II) are really nice--bamboo floors, granite counters, chrome appliances, etc. Even two buildings in the older section are nice--Flowers and Cooper. (I would stay away from the Hicks and Toms buildings because of poor noise barriers.) The area is safe, within walking distance to local eats and coffee shops, and within minutes of Duke University. WV staff is friendly and helpful. The prices are higher than renting a house in the area, but if you are social like me and want to walk everywhere, West Village is a good place to be.

2009 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/07/2009
West Village is very attractive for those wanting to move to downtown Durham, but there seem to be more students than young professionals despite the upper scale rent ranges and what the management says about their undergrad policy. Even in Phase II there are many students living here. It can be very loud at late hours, and my car has been hit and run in the parking lot (by a car with a Duke sticker). Had I known the demographic, I would have opted for one of the other residential loft spaces downtown.

2007 - 2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 09/16/2009
I've been living at WV for three years now and I love it! Of course it has a few downsides but most apartments do. I rent a two bed/two bath in phase I, and have been here for three years with a dog. Pros: Wonderful high ceilings, lots of light, designed for entertaining, VERY pet friendly( Really it's like a dog park, as a matter of fact I think they are constructing an enclosed space ), very clean hallways and grounds, You can modify your apt. just about any way you would like to., Two restaurants on site and lots more within 1 to 3 blocks, concierge, cleaning services, gym, pool, game room, 24/7 business center, prompt maintenance, safe and secure, courtyards with tables and grills and Very friendly neighbors (especially if you have a dog) Cons: Noise! (Phase I) if you live on the second floor you should invest in rugs. The noise barriers are crap. In one of my bathrooms I can literally hear every word of my neighbor s conversations. Lots of dust due to the age of the buildings. Having to carry groceries down long hallways (yes it can be a hike to your door). That's all of the bad points I can think of. In response to other reviews I've read, as far as vandalism goes....WV is "urban". Geezzzz the homeless shelter is less than a 10 minute walk away and social services is next door. I've had my side mirror destroyed and my window smashed but I still feel safe here after 3 years. I would say the only thing that bothers me is panhandlers. You may get two or three a month and most are ok with a "no" but every now and then some explicit words may be yelled at you. Hey if you don't love the lifestyle of urban living you won't like it here.

Report
Resident
2009 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/11/2009
I lived in two units in West Village over the span of about 3 years. Both were in the Phase I area, so my comments might not apply to whatever newer unit you're lookng at. Something that's interesting about West Village is that unlike every other apartment I've ever known, it attracts all ages of people (generally provided that they're childless). Rather than being a quiet unit mostly filled with seniors, or a raucous unit full of college students, you get a very interesting mix of people who often have nothing in common, ha ha. I'm all for diversity, but as a young professional, I found it very obnoxious to pay the rent that I did for the privilege of listening to spoiled college students (I'm a Duke alumna myself, but my parents sure weren't paying for me to live in WV) traipse drunkenly all over the building, while getting the sound police called on me by presumably older folk during a quiet dinner gathering. Although I know of several young professionals still living in West Village, I always sort of got the impression that the place was not made for people like myself. I've heard many people talk about safety on this board. I didn't feel unsafe living here at all, except my bicycle was stolen right out of the closed and monitored bike area. I wondered how this was even possible, to the point where I wondered if perhaps I'd left my bike somewhere else, until my neighbor's bike got stolen later that week, and when he pursued some sort of answer, all he got was that this was a common complaint. This was two years ago, so perhaps something has been done about this. My main issue with WV was probably the insulation. I didn't bother buying a television because I could hear my neighbors' at all times, and I assume that they were being played at a reasonable volume. I never dared listen to music without headphones. I'm a pretty relaxed person and rarely mind noise from the neighbors -- I knew when I moved in that this was a known issue and expected it. What I did not expect was that I would wind up living in fear of noise violations for the slightest activity of my own. Once, I had three friends over for dinner at 9pm on a friday. There was no music, no drinking, just 4 adults sharing conversation within inches of each other. A security officer gruffly knocked on my door and informed me that we were being too loud. I apologized and told my guests, who were astounded and a little creeped out that anyone could hear us outside the apartment. We immediately dropped our voices to practically a whisper, and in less than 10 minutes, the officer was back, this time incredibly rude to us. I lived on the first floor, we were talking at below-normal volume, and it was early on a Friday night -- even if we were being a little louder, which is really not the case, it seemed like an appropriate time and setting to entertain guests without disturbing the lives of the neighbors too much. One other thing that may be worth noting is that it may be worth considering if you have allergies. I never knew that I did, but developed what my optometrist diagnosed as allergic conjunctivitis when I was living in WV. I noticed that occasionally if I slept somewhere else, I'd wake up with clear eyes, so I invested in a better vacuum cleaner and cleaned my apartment even more psychotically than I typically do, hoping it would make a difference. It didn't, but my eye problem disappeared the day I moved out. I suspect that maybe all those open rafters are hard to really keep dust free. If you do elect to rent a WV apartment, I would try to find a unit that doesn't restrict your bed placement to an area directly under a vent -- I suspect that exacerbated the problem I had. All in all, West Village provides many nice perks (free coffee, 24-hour assistance number, office hours on the weekends), so if you're looking for a little extra pampering, it might be a great fit for you. In my experience, however, the management's extra involvement in my life proved more of a liability than a treat. My current apartment is much less attentive, but it's also much cheaper, much more insulated, and the residents much less uptight.

Resident
2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/06/2009
I'm an older professional woman who lived in Phase II (Cobb) for 10 months (2008-09) and thought it was just spectacular: beautiful, friendly, mostly quiet (when there wasn't construction going on), nicely located (walking distance from a variety of restaurants, Brightleaf, the bus and train stations, the YMCA, pubs and the West End Wine Bar, the farmers' market, a good film theater and other cultural centers). As for safety, right: it's not a rich suburb, and one stays alert. I myself routinely walked in the downtown environs at night without incident. I found the staff unfailingly helpful, efficient, and nice. Above all, I was struck by the sense of community--how neighbors, from students to young professionals, established people, artists, and retirees became at least acquainted. I also liked being part of the revival of downtown Durham. Great experience, and I plan to come back.

DowntownDog 04/04/2009

It may not seem credible to those who haven't lived here - but as a resident who's lived in 2 different buildings, I'm not surprised at all. 1) The buildings (at least 6 now) vary in construction quality and apartment amenities, and there's quite a range of sizes and layouts within them. 2) Particularly for smaller apartments, the rates are higher than for similar space in more "suburban" neighborhoods. People tend to either love it or hate it, depending on their unit, building, and what they're comparing it to. The "haters" tend to be students and young adults from the Toms & Hicks building, comparing it to garden apartments. It could easily seem overpriced and relatively unsafe from that point of view. Those with larger apartments in the other buildings and/or have lived downtown in other cities see it as safe, friendly, and a good buy. I can tell you we've lived here over 5 years, and our car has never been broken into. There is a new garage, and I'd highly recommend that anyone with a convertible spring for a space in it. There's no neighborhood in any city where I'd consider one safe parked outside.

2007 - 2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 01/23/2009
I moved to the area just over 2 years ago. I started my experience with West Village in Phase I and then moved over to Phase II after it was opened. I love the rustic character of Phase I, but decided to move to Phase II because I saw a unit with HUGE windows, stainless upgraded appliances ( I love to cook), fireplace, and washer and dryers in the unit...AND it still had the character of the exposed brick and beams and 26 ft ceilings! It seems like WV learned things from Phase I and applied them to Phase II. They were able to greatly reduce the noise by acoustically insulating each unit. They also installed trash chutes and recycling on each floor and added a pool and media center. I love the Wednesday Night Wine Nights in the courtyard and being able to walk to restaurants and bars. I also enjoy living in a community that has worked so hard to preserve the history of Durham.

Resident
2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 01/02/2009
I live in one of the "new" buildings, if you can call something constructed in 1899 new. First, let me say that I have no noise problem whatsoever. Sometimes I wonder if anyone else lives in this building, although I see people in the hallways, so I know they do. I think I have heard my neighbor's washing machine once but other than that it is quiet. There has been a party or two, but there is a safety officer on duty until 4 a.m. and they will take care of the issue. I occasionally hear a passing train but the tracks are very close and the fact I don't hear them more is amazing. Parking is fine, there is plenty, you might have to walk a little to some of the buildings (like a block) but I live here so I can walk so it doesn't bother me. I sometimes don't use my car for days; I can walk to work, restaurants, bars, pretty much anywhere I need to go. As for safety, I have no concerns. I walk my dog, at night, downtown. I also walk to and from downtown places like The Federal and Piedmont. As with any place, you need to be smart and aware of your surroundings. There is a lot of unfounded fear of downtown Durham in people who don't live here. Management has always been extremely responsive. They have fixed maintanence requests within 24 hours. The space is visually stimulating and beautiful. I love the 20 foot windows, exposed beams, and brick walls in my apartment. It is by far the best apartment I have ever lived in. One more thing, the complex is very pet friendly.

Resident
2000 - 2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 09/05/2008
West Village - where I have lived for 8 years - has responsive, helpful and effective management and maintance. That is to say, the management responds quickly and positively to requests for all maintaince and repair, never with"it's not our job." The noise level from neighbors does not exist. There is very little street noice - fire engins are the exception. Located in down town - there is shopping, food, entertainment, parks within walking distance. Public transportation is across the street for comuters. A police sub station is in the complex. Single women, children and elderly are safe. The residents are diverse economically, racially, age, gender, occupations and every other way I can think of. Over all, West Village rates as a 5 in each category (except parking) and overall is the best place to live in Durham or the Research Triangle area.

Resident
2008 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/26/2008
First off, the management has been very nice and helpful. I saw some reviews from the past say that management was awful, but I've had nothing but good experiences with them. Perhaps they have changed in those 4-5 years. There is plenty of parking, but it is really far from some of the apartments. This ties into safety - once you are in the complex, it is very safe because it is gated and coded, but waking from the parking areas to the gates can be a little unsettling at night. NOISE - Do you like hearing your neighbors have loud sex EVERY NIGHT? Do you like to hear your neighbor's Guitar Hero parties like they're happening in YOUR OWN APARTMENT? Do you like to hear every conversation your neighbor has or every television show they watch? If so, this is the place for you. If not, then stay far away... I know for a fact that Hicks building and Toms Building are AWFUL for this problem; I'm not sure about Flowers and the Garage. BUT SERIOUSLY, NOISE IS AN AWFUL PROBLEM. They built these apartments from the bottom up... why couldn't they include sound insulation? DEFINITELY NOT WORTH THE MONEY FOR SUCH A PROBLEM TO EXIST. Grounds - They're pretty, but I don't live on the grounds. I live in an apartment, so I just don't really care about grounds. Construction - some of the fixtures in the apartments are just awful. The mirrored closet doors are shoddy as heck, fall out of track all the time, get stuck, etc. Toilet innards seem to break WAY too often (thus messing up your water bill). The noise issue is just horrific, as I already said. Maintenance - The maintenance people have always been fast and very helpful. Overall, I'd say don't live here for more than a few months. It's great if you're between living situations, but to sign a year-long lease and then find yourself with loud sex next door every night, a leaky toilet all the time, and parking a quarter mile away at night... you don't want to be stuck with that for a year. It's a tolerable place for a short time, but that's about it. Also, it is SO expensive for what you get... If there weren't the noise problems and the shoddy fixtures, I really would feel like the price was fair and I'd have no problem with it... after all, I did sign up to live there ;) But, now that I have to live with the problems, it's not worth it. Ugh.
First off, the management has been very nice and helpful. I saw some reviews from the past say that management was awful, but I've had nothing but good experiences with them. Perhaps they have changed in those 4-5 years. There is plenty of parking, but it is really far from some of the apartments. This ties into safety - once you are in the complex, it is very safe because it is gated and coded, but waking from the parking areas to the gates can be a little unsettling at night. NOISE - Do you like hearing your neighbors have loud sex EVERY NIGHT? Do you like to hear your neighbor's Guitar Hero parties like they're happening in YOUR OWN APARTMENT? Do you like to hear every conversation your neighbor has or every television show they watch? If so, this is the place for you. If not, then stay far away... I know for a fact that Hicks building and Toms Building are AWFUL for this problem; I'm not sure about Flowers and the Garage. BUT SERIOUSLY, NOISE IS AN AWFUL PROBLEM. They built these apartments from the bottom up... why couldn't they include sound insulation? DEFINITELY NOT WORTH THE MONEY FOR SUCH A PROBLEM TO EXIST. Grounds - They're pretty, but I don't live on the grounds. I live in an apartment, so I just don't really care about grounds. Construction - some of the fixtures in the apartments are just awful. The mirrored closet doors are shoddy as heck, fall out of track all the time, get stuck, etc. Toilet innards seem to break WAY too often (thus messing up your water bill). The noise issue is just horrific, as I already said. Maintenance - The maintenance people have always been fast and very helpful. Overall, I'd say don't live here for more than a few months. Resident
2002 - 2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/23/2008
The complex is an adaptive re-use of industrial buildings from the tobacco business. All the buildings are architecturally interesting, with an industrial flavor - high ceilings, open ductwook, wood floors - yet well laid-out and functional as residences. However, some buildings are better built than others. Toms and Hicks were pure warehouses, so the windows are rather small, and if they fact north, the lofts can be a bit dark. Nor is the noise insulation as good as in Flowers and Cooper, which also have big windows and more natural light. (I can't speak to the new buildings.) The whole place is cool if you like living downtown and walking to restaurants, shops, a movie theater, the farmer's market, the ballpark, etc. There's plenty of parking, a great staff that goes out of their way to help, a gym, business center, and now a pool. Having a police sub-station in the complex is also nice. Apartments are most often available in Toms and Hicks, where the living is still darn good. But if you're at West Village for the long term and you can afford it, it's worth moving to one of the other buildings when there's an opening. Current residents get first crack. By the way, the address of the office is 604 W. Morgan St. 212 N. Duke is the Hicks building, purely residential and locked, so don't go there looking for the staff!

2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/04/2008
I've had the opportunity to sublet at West Village from May until August 2008 - the management is excellent. Very conscientious. Even if you need lightbulbs changed, call them. Love that they do valet garbage service at night. The grounds are kept very clean. I have a dog, love that the complex is pet friendly. This place is a very good deal in my opinion. One thing that is a bummer is that all apartments don't have decks. I wish I had one. Overall, I enjoyed my stay and enjoyed being close to the good things that Brightleaf square has to offer. I felt very safe as there is a police sub-station located in the complex. I'm picky and this place has definitely met all my expectations.

Resident
2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/28/2008
I was in Durham for four months and lived in one of West Villages corporate apartments. I LOVED living there, and miss it very much. The management staff was extremely accommodating and friendly. . . always willing to help with anything I needed. The location is fantastic, right in the middle of Durham's downtown district. There are so many cool things within walking distance! However, the neighborhood isn't exactly the best, a fact which is made better by West Village's surrounding gates. The only problem is that the parking lots are not gated, so sometimes coming home very late can be a little scary. That being said, I never had an actual problem with vagrants or crime. The apartments themselves are phenomenal, albeit very noisy. Invest in some earplugs for sleeping. . . you'll probably need them.

Resident
2007 - 2008 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/04/2008
I moved out of West Village after living there for a year. I could not find a roommate for my last undergraduate year at Duke, so I thought this was a cool place to live alone. I really like the architecture and the hard wood floors--really easy to maintain :) But there were a lot of issues. I never made any friends with anyone in my building. My neighbors were either very occupied or just not interested. So I tried to have my own friends over when I could. I don't think this is a place for college kids. Especially with the noise complaints. I might have gotten knocks on my door twice a week for my TV being too loud--when my volume was never above a 10 or 11.. it got to the point where I had to sit a foot from the television to hear it, just so I would not get an embarrassing noise complaint. I think the people who live in some of the buildings just have very low tolerance and are certainly impatient-- I probably could have called in noise complaints dozens of times-- but this is a living area, people are loud sometimes! The worst instance was while I was away on a trip for a week. I wasn't even in the same state and I got an extremely rude voicemail from management telling me I was to be evicted because a "party the night before was so loud and inappropriate the police had to be involved." I wasn't even home! Not the kind of call I wanted to receive. Apparently there was a mix-up with apartments, but I still don't understand how that could have happened. I still managed to have fun living there, but the "quiet hours" and noise complaints.. please.

2006 - 2007 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/06/2007
I've lived at West Village for over a year now and it is by far the best place I have ever lived. The office staff is incredibly helpful - they really go out of their way to help everyone who lives here. The maintenace techs are phenomenal and are willing to do things like hang paintings, install extra light fixtures, help mount flat screen tvs. What I've noticed looking through these reviews is that people either love it here or hate it - and for those who hated living here their greatest complaints were with the management. I have to wonder if there is a larger story there and we are just getting a dose of vitriol because something didn't go their way.

Resident
2005 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/25/2007
I lived in the West Village in 2005. When I first checked out the apartments, I was very impressed. I loved the exposed brick and wooden beams in the room that gave the West Village great character, especially compared to the multitude of ugly garden style buildings in Durham. The prices didn't seem too bad either for the large size of the apartment. However, within about a month of living there, I knew a made a big mistake. As mentioned in previous posts, there is no noise insulation so you can hear everything going on in your neighbors' apartments. The residents below me came to my door at least 10 times during the year to tell me not to walk in my own apartment with shoes and to not talk too loudly. I was horrified when the next door neighbor was able to tell me every television program I watch because he was able to hear everything through the walls. Next, the ceiling in my apartment leaked throughout the entire year despite the management's attempt to "fix" the problem (The Tom's building has a big problem with leaking). A lot of my clothes and books were destroyed and the carpet in one of the rooms smelled like mold as a result. The heating and air conditioning systems are poorly installed and there was no real climate control. Again, I brought this up to management and they were not able to do anything about it. A lot of people in the building are really snobby (including the management) and I always felt I was walking on eggshells with them. They somehow thought they were living in some fancy loft apartment in the West Village, Manhattan instead of the West Village, Durham, North Carolina. Some other posts mentioned how the building manager will find any way to deny returning your housing deposit. This is true. I spent a solid week making sure the place was spotless before I left because some of my friends that lived there and moved out earlier hadn't received their deposits for minor things like leaving a couple items in the fridge. Yet, despite my efforts, I never saw a dime of my deposit again. One last thing, the area is not safe at night and you will be a target since the upscale West Village is in an economically depressed neighborhood. Be careful. Please stay away from this place as it will only cause headaches and frustration.

I lived in 2 different apartments in West Village in 2002-2003 (I think!) when I was a student at Duke. I love the architecture and really wanted to make living there work out, but I wholeheartedly agree with every word of this well written commentary. I too did not get my security deposit back even though both apartments looked better when I moved out!

anonymous 09/26/2007

Wow!! This must be the noisy, rude neighbor that lived above me. Ran his dishwasher at 11PM, purchased a puppy and played fetch up and down the hall. Management was nice enough to pay for my move into another quiet downstairs apartment without a rude neighbor above me. I continued to live at West Village for another two years and recently moved out. I enjoyed the community and friendly, knowlegdeable office staff. Of course things broke in my apartment but maintenance was in to repair that day or the next. Wait till you purchase a home and see how easy it is to not have things breakdown. Can you imagine repairing over two hundred apartments at once.

Resident
2004 - 2007 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/19/2007
I've been living here for about 3 years. The attraction should be obvious: a rather nice scene at the Brightleaf area nearby, walking to a lot of places including parks, restaurants, ball games, art galleries, etc. The apartments are dominated by folks who are a bit older who are into the local scene, and there are plenty of Duke students around (even some undergrads). The place is gated, though the parking isn't, so I can understand why folks might be nervous late at night, though for someone who regularly comes home at odd hours, I've never had any real problems. It helps that there is a police substation in the complex. There is also nighttime security/24 on-call assistance at the office. I see the same regular handful of scam artists every six months or so. Panhandlers are quite harmless and are rather rare for a downtown area. They tend to stay closer to Ninth Street. The downtowns in Chapel Hill and Raleigh, frankly, have more of problem this way. I've found the staff to be very accomodating and fair, if strict. For example, I've knocked on the door of the maintenance person in my building after locking myself out, and he's let me back in, no fees, no unpleasantness. I adopted a large dog that other complexes would not have allowed based on his looks, and the management observed the dog one day, and gave their approval. They also helped me with my dog when I was in a bind one holiday. (There are a lot of dogs in the complex, big and small. We dog owners are careful to be considerate, there are clean-up stations in the courtyards, etc. We do chat and let our dogs say hello -- but not run around unleashed -- in the courtyards. Suffice to say, people who don't like dogs might not be too keen on the place.) There are plenty of cats too. The services offered are good. You won't find a pool, car wash or other more suburban amenities. There's a concierge service in the complex, fitness center that can be rather busy at peak times, package signing, etc. I think they still have dry cleaning pick-up. (I have my own place near work that I use.) Repairs are prompt when I report them, whether they're big or small. There aren't any washer-dryer hookups in the apartments, at least not right now. That might change with sub-metering the water, but right now each floor has a laundry room that uses a card system for payment. The old storage warehouses with the small windows still get a surprising amount of light. The ones with large factory windows obviously get tons of light. The floors are in good shape, though being old warehouses, they do "roll" a bit (more noticeable in the hallways than in the apartments). The HVAC and appliances are modern. The finishes and fixtures are good for apartments, but only fair by house standards. The brick construction, though, is great, and I don't have any problems with bugs, bats, rodents, whatever. I love that in some weather you can smell the dried tobacco (not burning tobacco) in the wood. The apartments generally lack closet space though. Be aware that all the interior walls stop about 10' above the floor and are open to the high ceilings. That might make some roommate arrangements, uh, uncomfortable. To me, it's pretty well-built with some inevitable gotchas due to the buildings being older and recycled. I've rarely had problems with sound from the neighboring apartments, though it's definitely there sometimes. The only real complaints I've had with regard to sound is some students being loud in the hallways on Friday or Saturday nights. It's rare though -- OK, three times in 3 years.

Resident
2006 - 2007 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/22/2007
I enjoyed living at West Village. Living at WV you can enjoy some beautiful, historic architecture, a living environment with a strong sense of community, and close proximity to the local Durham cultural and pub scene.<br><br>The apartments and the complex are all kept in excellent condition. Their maintenance team is very thorough and responsive: If you need a light bulb changed, you only need to call the office and within hours it is changed, and the maintenance person always leaves a note letting you know he was there. The management team, as well, is very responsive and professional. Sabrina has her hands full managing the team and the more than 200 apartments, but she does so with polite and patient professionalism. The other members of her team are exceptional, as well. <br><br>WV is very pet friendly. The management will from time to time leave out pet treats for the entire community to enjoy. There is free Wi-Fi, free cappucino, hot chocolate, and coffee; a comfortable recreation room with games and a community book exchange; a 24 hour good-sized fitness complex; and it seemd to me that most everyone living at WV took it upon themselves to be neighborly - not distant or cold. I really felt that I was part of a community there. <br><br>As in any city, sometimes finding a close parking place is not possible, but WV management has secured several satellite lots and so one is never sans a space...not ever. These satellite lots are across the street from the complex - thus, not at all far....and given that the Durham police have a substation at WV and park their own vehicles in the satellite lots it is fairly secure. <br><br>Regarding noise: I did not have much of a problem with noise at the complex, however, it is an issue at times. In those instances the management is very responsive in quelling the offenders and restoring peace. Within my own apartment I could hear the classic rock that my downstair's neighbor played some nights coming up through one of the large, defunct industrial pipes, but given that I sometimes liked to rock-out myself, fair is fair. I have little doubt that if I had asked my this neighbor to keep it down, he would have done so ---- since everyone really seems to care about each other at WV.<br><br>I think West Village is well worth the rent and one of the very best places to live in the triangle area. It is a place for urban adults who know how to be good neighbors. It is not the place for people who live in fear of Durham, or the city, or who can't handle putting up with some ambient noise here and there so that one can live in a beautiful, historic building.<br><br>Regards, Martini<br><br>

2006 Not Recommended Reviewed 03/06/2006
Although the building and apartments are beautiful, I am not crazy about the staff, parking or safety. One of the managers is an absolute snob and seems to look down on anyone and everyone--the other handful are pretty nice. Parking is a problem on the street especially if you are getting back late at night. I was most concerned when I got back after 10 p.m. and had to walk quite a ways to get to my apartment. I also had a few pandhandler problems and one guy come up to me who had supposedly just been released from jail. This is a fine apartment if you have a male roommate, but I wouldn't want a female to live here alone.

Resident
2001 - 2002 Not Recommended Reviewed 02/21/2006
I lived at West Village for 13 months in 2001-2002. <br>I picked it because it was beautiful and the area had sidewalks (coming from Europe, the scarcity of sidewalks in Durham was a major shock) and despite the very high rent (but I only was going to stay for a year).<br>I took a two bedroom, because the one- bedroom apartments were narrow and dark. The ceilings were very high, and I loved the hardwood floors and exposed bricks. It was a bit like living on a movie set, because it was pretty spectacular. The fitness room (which I only used twice) was quite cramped, but the laundry facilities were OK.<br><br>I realized pretty soon that I would have to partake very closely in my upstairs neighbor's sports passions. He also returned home late at night with friends, all of whom walked incessantly with tip-tap shoes and played marbles for long periods of time (at least, this is what it sounded like). If he had a cough, I suffered with him, and could hear most of his phone calls. <br><br>Within a month of my arrival, a guy simply entered my apartment from the deck (while I was there) to ask for money. Management blocked the bedroom window so that I could keep it open without anyone larger than a child coming in (but the intruder had used the patio door). They also installed a motion-activated light, but it did not give me a lot of security (and was terrible if I wanted to read outside, because I had to keep flapping the book and generally become very agitated every two minutes to get the light to come back on). <br><br>Three months later, another guy walked in (but the light came on just before he did...), with the same story of having run out of gas. I called the police promptly (as I had been told that I should have done that the first time around), and later the policeman called because he could not come in (strange, because everyone else could). Later, a cat came in (did not even activate the light), and after that a dog did. Anyway, I was never physically harmed, but it certainly made my evenings pretty tense. A colleague put a chain to my deck door, to limit access (but also air flow). Once I saw a guy on my neighbors' deck, while they were out of town, and when I called him about being there, he told me that he was a police officer engaged in an undercover operation... Three times water suddenly rained into my apartment from upstairs. <br><br>Management was pretty decent with me, friendly, added 1 month to my lease without raising my rent, and returned my deposit pretty promptly. I did not feel that they were sufficiently concerned about the security issues, though, but they pretty much responded to everything else. <br><br>Parking was a bit difficult at night, as I did not like parking on the street, given my experience with security (or lack thereof). Panhandlers approached me two or three times (but I was outside, so I took it better).<br><br>It was a very exciting year, but when I returned to the USA I went for a safer (and cheaper) place, alas- without sidewalks...

2005 Not Recommended Reviewed 12/15/2005
The buildings are gorgeous, but the apartments themselves were built on the cheap -- contertops, cabinetry, etc. are extremely low-end.<br><br>The noise is unbearable. As many others have said, one can hear every word spoken in the halls, through the walls, through the windows. Lofts are typically noisy, it is true, but these are off the map.<br><br>In my opinion, the staff/management was always attentive and professional. No problems to report there.<br><br>Urban typically means less safe than the suburbs, but the fact that this complex is one block away from the bus station is certainly not a plus.<br><br>I would think twice before signing on here. Living in the old warehouses is hip and trendy, but their prices are high for Durham. I moved from West Village into a MUCH nicer townhouse in a nicer, safer neighborhood -- still very close to downtown/Duke -- and now pay almost $200 less a month. For much more, I feel.

Resident
2003 - 2004 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/30/2004
The location is great - you can walk to tons of restaurants, galleries, book stores, a music store, ballgames, the Carolina Theater, etc. The historical buildings have interesting architectural features with wood floors and high ceilings. The management and maintenance staff are professional, helpful and efficient. The management staff bend over backward to make good residents happy, and the maintenance staff often go above and beyond the call of duty. The management provides a variety of events for residents, including the current Warehouse Blues series (open to the public). Seeing people walking their dogs in the courtyards provides a friendly, chatting atmosphere that I haven't experienced elsewhere. There's an interesting range of ages and professions among the tenants. Security is good, and I'd feel very safe here even without the presence of the police substation. Granted, the noise insulation and storage could be better, but if we hadn't found West Village we'd have turned down my company's relocation offer, since it's the only place in the Triange that I'd want to live in. After reading some of the other reviews on this site, I wonder if it's West Village's drug-free policy that really bothered them, since they're obviously on something to have that kind of attitude.

Resident
2003 Not Recommended Reviewed 12/26/2003
As one of the other writers said, no place is perfect. West Village is no exception. <br> <br>Postives: 1) Location, location, location. 2) Restoraton work on the buildings really is superb. 3) Management has been friendly and helpful to us (as much as apt management is capable of being) although I am not surprised to hear stories to the contrary. <br> <br>Negatives: 1) Excessively high rent for Durham 2) Business and fitness center are not well maintained (ask management to show you how well equipment works, and how often maintained during the tour). 3) Loft style apartments (in of themselves) do not allow a great deal of privacy - important if residents are sharing apt with roomates! 4) Insulation in between apartments in Toms and Hicks buildings. Run, do not walk, away from those. Eggshell-thin, very poorly insulated walls allow even conversational level neighbors´ voices to pass through (not ideal when a majority of residents are students who tend to stay up late). <br> <br>Wash - convenience to Tosca restaurant can be both a blessing, and a curse. Ask management about fraternity parties which are hosted by Tosca and run until past midnight. <br> <br>Overall - great for students with beacoup d´argent who like to party, OK for professionals, as long as not in Hicks or Toms buildings! <br> <br>Also of note, I did not notice any panhandlers, and did not experience any damage to my vehicle while living here.

2001 - 2003 Recommended Property Reviewed 11/11/2003
Very cool place to live in downtown Durham. You can walk to the movie theater, numerous restaurants/bars/shops, Bulls games, and Duke U. campus. Plenty of parking and very nice grounds; responsive and friendly staff. Residents are a good mix of 20´s-30´s and hi-tech/bio-tech/academic professionals. The apts are great--~18 ft. ceilings, wood floors, and exposed brick walls and beams. If you ever wanted to live in an authentic warehouse loft (but with modern amenities), this is it--and only marginally more expensive than the standard "cookie cutter" apts you find everywhere else. Very nice and unique!

Resident
2000 - 2003 Recommended Property Reviewed 07/02/2003
For an apartment complex in a downtown area, West Village is quite nice. The noise levels from the city outside and from your neighbors next door are very high, but outside noise is to be expected in a city. My one major complaint while living there was that the sound carries throughout the apartments. In your own apartment, you can hear your neighbor´s conversations (among other things). Earplugs are a necessity. <br> <br>The grounds are kept nicely, and mostly everyone is pet-friendly at West Village. You need to take precautions as you would living in any city, but the courtesy officers are sometimes helpful. <br> <br>Overall, I would recommend West Village to someone looking for a unique, urban (usually loud) living environment.

My one major complaint while living there was that the sound carries throughout the apartments. In your own apartment, you can hear your neighbor´s conversations (among other things). Earplugs are a necessity. <br> <br>The grounds are kept nicely, and mostly everyone is pet-friendly at West Village. You need to take precautions as you would living in any city, but the courtesy officers are sometimes helpful. <br> <br>Overall, I would recommend West Village to someone looking for a unique, urban (usually loud) living environment. Read less

2001 - 2003 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/15/2003
West Village apartments are admittedly a bit overpriced for the area, and you might feel a bit more "trendy" than you really are at first. The apartments are gorgeous though and I really liked the 30 second walk to restaurants and stores in Brightleaf Square. They always seemed responsive to me and I never had any real problems with the place. Don´t keep valuables lying in your car overnight, but otherwise, it´s a safe area.

Resident
2000 - 2002 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/10/2002
The buzz is about that a less-than-favorable review of West Village has recently appeared on this site. While I do not normally do this sort of thing, I felt compelled to respond after reading that review. <br> <br>I have lived at West Village for almost two years now and have been very happy to do so. Is it perfect? Definitely not. It is on the expensive end as apartments in this area go and, yes, it is in downtown Durham and has some of the problems that downtown living can present. But we have weighed these issues against living in one of many virtually identical, for the most part, cheaply constructed, boxes and have never reqretted our choice. There are still mornings when the bright sunlight is pouring through the huge windows in our home that I marvel at just how fortunate we were to discover this place. <br> <br>We have met great people from all walks of life and from all over the world and made wonderful friends here. We feel that the management of the complex genuinely want to keep us here and have been very responsive to our needs. Again, does this mean that we never have a concern or a problem? Of course not, but when we do, the management has always attempted to resolve things quickly and to our satisfaction. <br> <br>In conclusion, is West Village perfect? No, but I have rented and/or owned in three different countries and I have yet to find perfection. What we have found here is close enough that we think we´ll stay on for a while.

Resident
2001 - 2002 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/06/2002
I am so happy for an opportunity to tell others about my horrible experience at West Village, and perhaps help them not to make the same mistake. <br> <br>Very Important: Do not be lured in by the visual appeal of these apartments! The "wow" factor of these apartments is not worth the trade off of misery! <br> <br>First of all, the apartments were not correctly soundproofed. For example, I can hear my neighbors sneeze and that is not the WORST I can hear. They are in the process of covering up that mistake, but it´s really not making much difference. <br> <br>Secondly, the management is HORRENDOUS. They are biased and feeble. Preferential treatment is given to some tenants (those dating the management, those with threatening lawyers, and those whose lease is up for renewal), but not all tenants. Rules and policy application vary from day to day, person to person. Be warned! <br> <br>The amount of vandalism and theft is also growing in the area. There are frequent car break-ins and lately, review mirrors are being knocked off cars for no reason. Please beware and check with the police to get actual numbers of larceny and other crimes in the area. The pan handler situation is also getting out of hand. Although the court yard is gated now, they still get you in the parking lot. I DO NOT feel safe knowing that the person I just refused to give money saw which car I just got out from... <br> <br>Basically, I just want apartment seekers to know that this was the most miserable place I have ever lived. Your hard earned money will be better spent somewhere else. There IS a reason why so many people I know have broken their leases early and have paid the EXTRA money just so they could escape... <br> <br>I want to be perfectly clear that I DO NOT have a personal vendetta against West Village. I just feel I have a personal obligation for someone who has experience with the living quarters, to warn others from making the same mistake. <br> <br>I hope this helps with your decision.

Resident
2000 - 2002 Not Recommended Reviewed 04/14/2002
West Village not only has physical issues that would make me recommend for someone not to move here (i.e. extremely poor soundproofing, not enough close parking, and maintenance/contractors that don´t complete work properly) but it has MAJOR problems in its management staff. They are either unable or unwilling to enforce community standards and rules (trash disposal, noise levels, removal of pet waste etc.). The apartment manager herself is very uncooperative and apparently, can read the future, (ha ha) since she responded to a rental history verification by stating that we had broken our lease (it isn´t up yet and we have yet to leave). When my spouse mentioned a maintenance issue that was unresolved after several attempts by myself to get someone to fix it (including a conversation I personally had with her about said issue) she told him that WE were negligent for not telling her it had not been fixed, even though all she had to do was ask us if the issue was resolved. She also threatened to take us in front of the magistrate for this so-called negligence. I´m pretty sure that our only obligation to West Village is to keep the unit in reasonable shape and to pay rent. Both of which we do unquestionably. <br> <br>If this type of a nightmare doesn´t appeal to you.... stay away!!! <br> <br>P.S. I would normally not post something anonymously, but I am very hesistant to give my name as the manager has already demonstrated her vindictive side... I have to live here a little while longer and want to try to keep it as peaceful as possible!
